messageBody:
The thread about a QS newsletter was listed under the subject of New
Members, which was unfortunate. Therefore, I am changing the subject,
and new posts about this topic should be under this subject line:
"Newsletter."

1) There is the problem of posting in QS to Yahoo groups, which seems
somewhat problematical due to difficulties that different browsers have
in displaying a QS font. I am not that knowledgeable about what causes
these problems, but it has been evident that some browsers have more
problems than others. Has anyone tested this? If so, do you know which
browsers work the best? Besides the idea of a newsletter, if we could
post more messages in QS, I am confident it would help everyone's
reading ability. There is an indisputable irony that on a site devoted
to the spread and use of an improved English alphabet, the peculiarities
of the internet as it has developed has insured that we continue to
write in TO almost exclusively.

2) I would expect that a newsletter would be uploaded to the
Read_Alphabet site where it would remain available for future download.
However, I wonder if there is a practical way to distribute a newsletter
more broadly? Should a download of a newsletter include a copy of the
alphabet with truncated rules for use? Or should a copy of the alphabet
be positioned next to the newsletter download so that those needing a
copy can easily obtain it?

3) What program should be used to produce a newsletter. And what
program would a person need to be able to open it? Should it contain
just printed news, or should photos with QS captions be included along
with other features.

4) How much material should a newsletter contain and how frequently
should it be produced? If we produce material on a regular basis, we
might expect that people would become more interested if they saw text
in the alphabet to read. How can we expect to interest people in the
alphabet if there is virtually nothing to read in it?

5) Just as in the open source paradigm, many people cooperate to
produce products that rival corporate offerings, if several of us work
together, we should be able to produce a newsletter that would be
interesting for QS aficionados to read.

6) What topics should be covered? As someone else wrote, I would think
that general interest stories would be best as there would not be enough
news about QS to produce a newsletter on any regular basis.

7) Copy for a newsletter cannot violate copyright laws.

8) This is farther afield, but it just popped into my head. I assume
that a QS crossword puzzle in a newsletter should work fine, but TO
puzzles are based on a "proper" spelling. Since words spelled in QS are
based on the writer's pronunciation, an unusual pronunciation might make
the puzzle harder. Of course, that could be considered part of the
difficulty of the puzzle. It could mean that it would help to know
where the puzzle-maker hails from. :-)

Obviously, I am proficient about thinking up questions. Anyone have any
answers or any other questions they would like to pose? Anyone is
welcome to start their own thread under this general one about a newsletter.


Cheers,

Paige
